title.value: Pioneering women in nuclear and radiation sciences
title.justification: The title matches the focus of the paper which is on the contributions of pioneering women in nuclear and radiation sciences.
title.quote: Pioneering women in nuclear and radiation sciences

extractions.description: This review provides a historical summary of contributions from pioneering women in radiation science, highlighting their work in nuclear and radiation sciences. It discusses the challenges faced by women scientists, their contributions to the field, and their role as potential role models for future generations.

type.justification: The paper is a historical review focusing on recording past contributions and challenges faced by pioneering women in nuclear and radiation sciences, rather than conducting new empirical research.
type.quote: This review provides a concise historical summary of contributions from a selected group of pioneering women in radiation science.

name.justification: The paper focuses on contributions in the domain of nuclear and radiation sciences by pioneering women.
name.quote: This review provides a concise historical summary of contributions from a selected group of pioneering women in radiation science.

name.justification: The paper highlights contributions to nuclear sciences as a key aspect of its focus on pioneering women in radiation science.
name.quote: This paper highlights a few groundbreaking contributions that women have made in the fields of nuclear and radiation science.

name.justification: Contributions to the field of medical physics are cited as part of the impact of pioneering women in radiation sciences.
name.quote: The pioneering work of the Polish-born French physicist and radio­chemist Marie Sklodowska-Curie (1867–1934) led to the fields of what is known today as medical physics and radiation oncology.

name.justification: The paper discusses the impact of pioneering women in the development of radiation oncology as a field.
name.quote: The pioneering work of the Polish-born French physicist and radio­chemist Marie Sklodowska-Curie (1867–1934) led to the fields of what is known today as medical physics and radiation oncology.
